@BattleDave1 Man, it's so weird to think that in 2001, I was just out of high-school. Didn't have a chance to imagine how my teachers would have handled this--but I like to think with vulnerability and honesty. Hell, who knows.
@wicked__j The next few days are going to be crucial, and I’m sitting here just watching it all with absolutely NO idea how it can and will play out. :/
@mybigcity Good class, tbh. Good kids. They’re awesome, and it makes me happy to know they’ve got their eyes on the world around them.
@Scoutdwriter I hope you are able to keep in touch with them, Scout! I can’t even imagine being that close to it all. :(

@AmandaODonovan9 I hope your professors moving forward give you that chance, too! And if anything, there are some amazing campus groups out there that are no doubt going to invite new folks into the fold for conversation and belonging!
@1mpavidus I get stuck in that place of inaction and fear too. Because I don’t know if there even is a way to help. Being able to read from reliable sources today has been such a huge help. <3
@keiralanebooks <3 I hope your kids find solace in knowing that they don’t have to know it all, and that being afraid, concerned, or confused is totally normal. You are a rockstar of a Mom, Keira.
@keiralanebooks I do too. A lot of people really talk down on kids nowadays, and they continuously astonish me. Their world is full of information and they parse abs process it so well.

I opened class giving them space to talk about their concerns over the crisis in Ukraine—not just as a teacher, but as a peer who shared their fear. Macbeth could wait. 

They know this is a world event, and it is on their minds. It’s on mine. It’s on yours.

Today I had a student afraid for a relative in Ukraine. 

Another feared what implications this might have on their loved ones in Taiwan. 

Yet another was concerned how Lebanon might be swept up in it all. 

Kids know. They listen. They read.

So be ready to listen too.

@CosmicTaryn It really is! I freaking love this show. I love its willingness to dance with nostalgia and also its honesty in pointing out both the problems with and advantages of martial arts practice.
@CmagStoryteller Right!? The amount of people who are like "lol Cobra Kai is absolutely unbelievable" and...like, Christ, it's so 100% accurate. It's almost documentary-level accurate.

A ton of martial arts schools are and still are dominated by a white male demographic of ego and competition--even in arts that decry direct competition. This show is EXACTLY how they work, both within styles and in regards to other styles.

#CobraKai may seem ridiculous, overblown, and dramatic, but I can assure you, it's exactly what happens when white dudes, their machismo, and toxic masculinity come crashing together unchecked in martial arts circles and beyond. 

This show knows it. The writing is stellar.
